channel.title: Will Hanley | Historical International Legal Computational
channel.description: Recent content on Will Hanley | Historical International Legal Computational

item.title: Egypt's cabinets in Wikidata
item.description: I am a hater of Wikipedia haters. It drives me up the wall when my kids' history teachers ban them from using it.

item.title: Pashas into Wikidata
item.description: I am experimenting with Wikidata as a research data repository. If I systematically upload various datasets, can I a) make wikidata more global and useful, and b) learn more about my own evidence?

item.title: About
item.description: I am a legal and social historian of the Middle East.

item.title: Why are Israel, UAE, and Bahrain signing agreements and racing the Tour de France?
item.description: It's the last days of the Tour. UAE, Bahrain, and Israel each sponsor a team.

item.title: FSU must lead on pedestrian safety
item.description: In December 2011, I attended a packed meeting at the Student Union at FSU.

item.title: Documentation, Tutorials, and Teaching
item.description: I continue to learn how to document my own work. If it helps others, great.

item.title: Academic and general writing
item.description: I post my academic work, including downloadable PDFs, in Zenodo’s repositories or via my ORCID profile.

item.title: Datasets to share
item.description: I’m committed to data sharing and reuse. I post data I’ve used or am using on github.

item.title: Standalone projects
item.description: I’ve undertaken a few standalone projects. Digital Egyptian gazette dig-eg-gaz.github.io

item.title: Charter Circumlocution
item.description: E pluribus unum (out of many, one) has been an American maxim since the late 18th century.

item.title: A Belgian Bombing in Istanbul: How Small States Manage Terrorist Moments
item.description: A century and a decade ago, an Istanbul court sentenced a Belgian named Edouard Joris to death for his part in a bomb attack on the Ottoman sultan.
